newsitem.title: UK: Britain's Clarke steals show at Tory conference.
newsitem.headline: Britain's Clarke steals show at Tory conference.

text.p: British Chancellor of the Exchequer Kenneth Clarke became the unlikely darling of the Conservative Party Conference on Thursday even though he made no promise of sweeping pre-election tax cuts in his set-piece speech.
Party activists, many of whom had been previously muted in their support for Clarke, gave the Chancellor a five minute standing ovation, the longest applause in the week so far.
Clarke's supporters were clearly relieved. They had been concerned the conference would give the Chancellor a cool reception because of his stance on Europe and tax.
Close colleague Quentin Davies told Reuters Clarke's speech was "the best of his life" and Deputy Prime Minister Michael Heseltine called it "fabulous".
Delegates leaving the conference hall were clearly converted.

"It was so obviously a brilliant speech. He's proved his metal and people will find it more difficult to criticise him now," said Murray Case from Welwyn and Hatfield constituency party. He said he was not generally a strong supporter of Clarke and wanted to see bigger tax cuts than have so far been hinted at.
Peter O'Brian, from a neighbouring Hertfordshire constituency, said he was happy with the line Clarke had taken on tax cuts, that he would only make them if affordable.
"I only want to see sustainable tax cuts, but I'm pretty confident we'll get something in November."
At last year's conference, Clarke teased the audience with the prospect of tax cut. He took a much harder line on Thursday.
Clarke repeated his claim that the public would not trust the Tories if they tried to buy the next election by unsustainable tax cuts. "We will only cut taxes when we can afford to."

Some delegates said they were still concerned Clarke was more interested in meeting the Maastricht criterian on fiscal deficits than cutting taxes as much a possible, but they appeared relieved Clarke stuck firmly to the goverment's line on a single currency.
The party leadership said it will keep its options open on EMU and not commit Britain to anything until it had to.
"That is a good policy and one the party can unite on. I'm pleased Clarke is keeping is sticking to it," said a delegate from Bolton.

Clarke sparked uproar last month and left right wingers baying for his dismissal when he sid it would be "pathetic" for Britain to dither over joining a single currency, then sign up at the last minute.

And some activists and party colleagues said on Thursday they still want to see the party leadership make a decision one way or another before they go to the polls. An election must be held by May 1997 at the latest.

"We've got to make a decision about what we think before the election," said David Heathcoat-Amory a leading Eurosceptic. "Obviously the Chancellor's speech is not the place to do it and today we can celebrate a very good speech from a very good Chancellor."
